title: Fund wizard
body: The Fund wizard lets you set up a fund or edit settings for an existing fund in FA Fund Management app. When you set up a fund in the FA Fund management app, FA creates a fund portfolio with the specified properties in FA Back to store the fund information and manage fund investments.

title: Fund wizard
body: To set up a new fund, click the Add fund button at the top-right of the NAV status view. To view and edit the settings of an existing fund, click the Edit fund button in the Fund details pane.

title: Fund wizard
body: The Fund wizard fields are described below.

title: Basic info tab
body: The Basic info tab contains the basic information about the fund.

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund company*

title: Basic info tab
body: A company the fund is administered by. Choose the company from the list of contacts available in FA Back.

title: Basic info tab
body: Language*

title: Basic info tab
body: The language to be used in portfolio reports. If the language is filled in the fund company's contact in FA Back, it is automatically copied to the Fund wizard when you set up a fund.

title: Basic info tab
body: Juridical*

title: Basic info tab
body: Juridical form of the fund company. Copied from the company's contact in FA Back.

title: Basic info tab
body: Name*

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund name.

title: Basic info tab
body: ID*

title: Basic info tab
body: A unique fund ID used to identify the fund and search for funds. Best practice is not to include special characters in the ID – only use numbers and letters (a-z).

title: Basic info tab
body: Currency*

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund currency. Once you create a fund, the currency can't be changed.

title: Basic info tab
body: Valuation method*

title: Basic info tab
body: Valuation method for the fund portfolio:

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price with adjustments – Uses transaction types that control the market value of the positions with the transaction's trade amount, such as Private Equity transaction types.

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price with separate items – Valuates portfolio with average price, but keeps track of original purchase dates.

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO (combined) – Valuates the portfolio based directly on transactions in the subportfolios.

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO with adjustments – Uses transaction types that control the market value of the positions with the transaction's trade amount, such as Private Equity transaction types.

title: Basic info tab
body: Type*

title: Basic info tab
body: Portfolio type. Choose the type that corresponds to the fund portfolio.

title: Cash accounts
body: Cash accounts for the fund.

title: Cash accounts
body: Name*

title: Cash accounts
body: Account name.

title: Cash accounts
body: Currency*

title: Cash accounts
body: Account currency.

title: Cash accounts
body: Account number*

title: Cash accounts
body: The account number, for example, the bank account number.

title: Cash accounts
body: Set as default account

title: Cash accounts
body: Set the account as the default account of the portfolio. All transactions are by default created against this account.

title: Schedules tab
body: The Schedules tab contains schedule settings for calculating NAV, fees, and unofficial NAV for the fund. Schedules let you track your fund's status. For example, you can see if NAV or fees have to be calculated today. You need to fill in the dates only once. After that, dates are updated every time you accept the calculation.

title: Schedules tab
body: The Schedules tab features settings for different workflows. You can set a schedule to calculate:

title: Schedules tab
body: NAV and fees as a part of regular NAV calculation workflow.

title: Schedules tab
body: Fees, in addition to the regular NAV calculation schedule, between the regular NAV calculation dates (to set a schedule for this workflow, click Add separate fee calculation schedule).

title: Schedules tab
body: Performance fee with equalization method (to set a schedule for performance fee equalization, click Add fee crystallization schedule). You can also use the same schedule for fee capitalization if you have chosen it in fee settings on the Fee structure tab.

title: Schedules tab
body: Unofficial NAV for reporting purposes between the scheduled regular NAV calculations (to set a schedule for this workflow, click Add unofficial NAV calculation schedule).

title: Schedules tab
body: To learn more about calculation workflows, see Workflows and NAV statuses.

title: Schedules tab
body: Frequency

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculation frequency: daily, weekly, every two weeks, and so on.

title: Schedules tab
body: If you want to make calculations without a preset schedule, choose "No schedule" and select Allow non-scheduled calculations below. This option is available for NAV, fees, and unofficial NAV calculations.

title: Schedules tab
body: Holiday calendar

title: Schedules tab
body: The holiday calendar to take into account in the calculation schedule. If you don't find a suitable holiday calendar from the list, you can create a calendar in FA Back (for details, see Preferences - Securities in the FA Back reference).

title: Schedules tab
body: Roll convention

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculation schedule based on the day of the month or day of the week. One of the most common roll conventions is "EOM" (end-of-month).

title: Schedules tab
body: You set the calculation frequency to "Every three months" and the first calculation date is on June 30th. The calculation dates will fall on the 30th of each month (September 30th, December 30th, March 30th, and so on). For months with 31 days, the calculation date won't be the last day of the month. If you choose the "End of Month (EOM)" roll convention, the system will recognize that June 30th is the last day of the month, and the calculation dates will fall on the last day of each month (September 30th, December 31st, March 31st, and so on).

title: Schedules tab
body: Business day convention

title: Schedules tab
body: Business day convention determines how to adjust a date if it falls on a non-business day.

title: Schedules tab
body: First date

title: Schedules tab
body: The date for which the calculation is made for the first time.

title: Schedules tab
body: Previous date

title: Schedules tab
body: The date for which the latest NAV or fees were calculated. For the newly created fund, previous NAV date must be the same as the first NAV date.

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculation delay in days

title: Schedules tab
body: The number of days between the NAV or fees date and the calculation date. Enter "0" to calculate NAV or fees on the same date, or choose the number of days to calculate NAV or fees with a delay.

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculate next days

title: Schedules tab
body: The button sets the next NAV or fees date and calculation dates according to the information entered above.

title: Schedules tab
body: Next NAV date

title: Schedules tab
body: The next NAV or fees date based on the frequency, holiday calendar conventions and the first NAV or fees date chosen above.

title: Schedules tab
body: Previous calculation date

title: Schedules tab
body: Previous calculation date based on the previous NAV or fees date and calculation delay.

title: Schedules tab
body: Next calculation date

title: Schedules tab
body: Next calculation date based on the next NAV or fees date and calculation delay.

title: Schedules tab
body: Allow non-scheduled calculations

title: Schedules tab
body: Allows starting a calculation outside the schedule, when the fund has "No action" status. For example, this can be useful in case you don't calculate scheduled NAV often but there are big movements in fund’s capital that affect the valuation of the fund. The Allow non-scheduled calculations option is available for NAV, fees, and unofficial NAV calculations.

title: Schedules tab
body: Non-scheduled NAV calculation result is shown in the NAV window. The calculation date is shown in the Latest NAV column in the NAV status view.

title: Fee structure tab
body: The Fee structure tab lets you set or edit the fees applied to the whole fund.

title: Fee structure tab
body: To add fees per share class, use the Share class wizardhur.

title: Fund fees
body: The Fund fees section lists the fund fees. To add a fee formula, click the Add fee button at the top-right.

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula used to calculate the fee and generate fee transaction.

title: Fund fees
body: Fee transaction type

title: Fund fees
body: Transaction type linked to the chosen fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Amount or %

title: Fund fees
body: Fee percentage or amount in the fund currency, depending on the fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Decimals

title: Fund fees
body: The number of decimals used for calculating fees (0 to 10). The "Default" value is 2 decimals.

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category for the fee. The categorization is used in cost analysis and reporting (see View ex-post costs and charges in FA User guide), as well as for creating kickbacks (see Rebate contracts (kickbacks) in FA User guide).

title: Fund fees
body: Additional options

title: Fund fees
body: Additional fee setups.

title: Fund fees
body: Calculate fee per security

title: Fund fees
body: Run the formula multiple times, for each security in the fund investment portfolio. Used, for example, for kickbacks.

title: Fund fees
body: Formula sets its own account

title: Fund fees
body: Create an account for the fee formula. For example, it can be useful with accrued account interest transactions over multiple accounts.

title: Fund fees
body: Include in income distribution

title: Fund fees
body: Include the fee in the income distribution calculation.

title: Fund fees
body: Use crystallization schedule for capitalization

title: Fund fees
body: Capitalize fees automatically on the crystallization date when you accept NAV. The crystallization dates are defined in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab. Fees are capitalized to the account that has the “Fee capitalization” tag. If no account is marked with this tag, fees are capitalized to the default cash account.

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: The Alternative fee calculation modes section contains advanced settings that affect fee handling in the NAV calculation. Leave the selections unticked for regular fee handling.

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Include fees calculated since the previous NAV calculation date in the current NAV calculation (if fees are calculated separately from NAV)

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Take the fees calculated since previous NAV calculation into account when calculating the current NAV.

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Allocate fees per share class from the beginning of the fund (for example, for private equity funds)

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Calculate fees per share class since the beginning of the fund (not since the latest NAV calculation). To learn more, see NAV calculation.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The Performance fee equalization section contains the fee formula to use if you calculate performance fee and equalize it regularly according to the crystallization schedule. In addition to choosing the fee formula here, you need to define the crystallization schedule in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab, and the fee parameters in the Share class wizard, Fee structure tab.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Select Calculate performance equalization fee with contingent redemption method and fill in the fields to define the fee settings:

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee formula

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee formula used to calculate performance fee transactions: choose "Performance fee with crystallization".

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee transaction type

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Transaction type linked to the chosen performance fee formula.

title: Fund reporting tab
body: The Fund reporting tab lets you define the settings to produce fund reporting data, including fund KPIs, and store it in the FA Fund Management app (see Fund reporting view for details). Click Enable fund reporting and fill in the fields.

title: Fund reporting tab
body: Reporting schedule

title: Fund reporting tab
body: The settings for the fund reporting schedule are similar to NAV and fee calculation schedules (see Schedules tab).

title: Fund reporting tab
body: Allocation groups

title: Fund reporting tab
body: Allocation groups to analyze the fund portfolio contents. To learn more about allocations, see Allocation in the FA Back reference.

title: Order execution tab
body: The Order execution tab lets you define and edit the automatic trade order execution settings.

title: Order execution tab
body: Cut-off time

title: Order execution tab
body: The cut-off time for the fund in 24 h format, for example, “13:00”. After you set the cut-off time, you can use decision tables make sure that certain transactions or trade orders that come after the cut-off time don't affect the NAV calculation. To learn more, see Set up a mutual fund.

title: Order execution tab
body: Enable automatic order execution

title: Order execution tab
body: Enable automatic order execution and create transactions ofr the fund when NAV is accepted.

title: Order execution tab
body: Default transaction types

title: Order execution tab
body: Transaction types for the cash transactions (unit holder deposits and withdrawals).

title: Order execution tab
body: Account for cash transactions

title: Order execution tab
body: Account number for the cash transactions. Leave the field empty to use the default account.

title: Order execution tab
body: Transaction types for bookkeeping

title: Order execution tab
body: For bookkeeping purposes, you can provide transaction types that are used when creating cash transaction for client orders whose settlement date doesn’t follow the default logic.

title: Order execution tab
body: Leave these transaction types empty to use the accounts for cash transactions instead.

title: Client orders
body: Settlement cycle

title: Client orders
body: Setting to define the settlement date for subscriptions and redemptions if it is missing in the client order. Enter the number of days after the transaction date.

title: Client orders
body: Account for client transactions

title: Client orders
body: Account used for client transactions created from trade orders.

title: Client orders
body: Use the account of the trade order to transactions

title: Client orders
body: Use the currency account (or default account) to transactions

title: Client orders
body: Use the default account to transactions

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Default transaction types

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Transaction types for the cash transactions (unit holder deposits and withdrawals).

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Account for cash transactions

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Account number for the cash transactions. Leave the field empty to use the default account.

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Transaction types for bookkeeping

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: For bookkeeping purposes, you can provide transaction types that are used when creating cash transaction for client orders whose settlement date doesn’t follow the default logic.

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Leave these transaction types empty to use the accounts for cash transactions instead.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: The NAV reporting tab features options for setting up custom NAV reports and sending NAV reports by email.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: NAV report PDF template

title: NAV reporting tab
body: The path to the PDF template used for building NAV reports. The path to the default template is pre-filled for you. To use a custom template, enter the template path in the field. To learn more about configuring custom reports, see Customize the NAV report (XLSX) in FA Developer guide.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: NAV report XLSX template

title: NAV reporting tab
body: The path to the XSLX template used for building NAV reports. The path to the default template is pre-filled for you. To use a custom template, enter the template path in the field. To learn more about configuring custom reports, see Customize the NAV report (XLSX) in FA Developer guide.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Send report via email

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Enable sending NAV reports by email. You can send NAV reports by email from FA Back (for instructions, see Send documents via email). We recommend that your administrator schedules the report sending in Tools → Administer → Scheduled functions in FA Back. For example, you can have the emails sent out every afternoon on the days when you calculate NAV.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Recipients

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Emails to send the reports to. Email addresses in this field are automatically added to the "Report via email" list of emails in FA Back, meaning that all other reports that are generated for the fund are sent to this email too.

title: Swing pricing tab
body: The Swing pricing tab lets you define settings for swing pricing. Click Apply swing pricing and fill in the fields.

title: Swing pricing tab
body: Official NAV

title: Swing pricing tab
body: A setting to choose how swing adjustment is used in your fund. Choose one of the options:

title: Swing pricing tab
body: Swung NAV - Swing adjustment is included in official NAV. The logic of handling swing adjustment is shown in the table.

title: Swing pricing tab
body: Unswung NAV – Swing adjustment is not included in official NAV. The logic of handling swing adjustment is shown in the table.

title: Swing factor
body: Swing factor is used for adjusting the unit price.

title: Swing factor
body: For swinging up

title: Swing factor
body: The percentage to adjust the unit price if the net inflow of the fund exceeds the threshold.

title: Swing factor
body: For swinging down

title: Swing factor
body: The percentage to adjust the unit price if the net outflow of the fund exceeds the threshold.

title: Thresholds
body: Swing thresholds are the net inflow or net outflow of the fund that triggers the adjustment to the NAV. You can set a threshold in fund currency or as a percentage of the fund's total net asset value on the NAV date.

title: Thresholds
body: For swinging up

title: Thresholds
body: Net inflow that triggers swinging up.

title: Thresholds
body: For swinging down

title: Thresholds
body: Net outflow that triggers swinging down.

title: Income distribution tab
body: The Income distribution tab features settings for keeping track of the fund's accrued income and calculating the tax on it if needed. FA Fund Management app calculates the accrued income based on the bookkeeping postings and records the result into your fund every time you calculate NAV. You can choose to calculate tax on the accrued income at the same time.

title: Income distribution tab
body: After NAV is calculated, the system creates transactions for accrued income and calculated tax. The calculation also allocates accrued income per share class in security market data (Security window, Market data tab in FA Back) while pricing the share classes with NAV.

title: Income distribution tab
body: Click Enable income distribution and fill in the fields.

title: Accrued income
body: Settings to calculate accrued income.

title: Accrued income
body: Accrued income formula

title: Accrued income
body: Fee formula to calculate accrued income. Accrued income is calculated every time you calculate NAV.

title: Accrued income
body: Fee formula can be specified either for the whole fund or for a share class (not for both). Make sure that you don’t have any fee formulas in the Share class wizard, Fee structure tab if you use fund-level rules and the other way round.

title: Accrued income
body: Transaction type

title: Accrued income
body: Type of the transaction generated by the accrued income formula.

title: Accrued income
body: Bookkeeping accounts used to calculate income distributions

title: Accrued income
body: Fields for bookkeeping accounts to track accrued income. When you calculate NAV, FA sums up the balances on the specified bookkeeping accounts on the NAV date. To enter multiple account numbers, separate them with a semicolon. To include only part of the account balance in the calculation, enter a percentage after the account number. For example, "123456=45,5" means that 45,5% of the 123456 account balance is used in the calculation.

title: Accrued income
body: Mark all “Ready” bookkeeping postings from start of the year to the NAV date as “Reported” when NAV is accepted

title: Accrued income
body: Change the status of bookkeeping postings produced by income distribution when the NAV is accepted. In most cases, you need to have this option selected.

title: Accrued tax
body: Settings to calculate tax on accrued income.

title: Accrued tax
body: Calculate tax of the accrued income distribution

title: Accrued tax
body: Option to record tax to be paid on the accrued income. Fill in the tax parameters below.

title: Accrued tax
body: Tax formula

title: Accrued tax
body: Fee formula used to calculate tax on accrued income.

title: Accrued tax
body: Transaction type

title: Accrued tax
body: Type of the transaction generated by the tax formula.

title: Accrued tax
body: Tax percentage

title: Accrued tax
body: Percentage of accrued income to be paid as tax.

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Settings for income distribution breakdown.

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Par value (the first NAV value)

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Par value used to break down cash transactions.

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Par value account

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Income distribution account

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Over/ under value account

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Transaction fees account

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Accounts to break down the cash transaction trade amount.

title: Accounting tab
body: The Accounting tab lets you define accounts and rules for generating postings for income distribution (for other income distribution settings, see Income distribution tab .

title: Accounting tab
body: Automated deferral runs before NAV calculation

title: Accounting tab
body: Settings for deferral runs before NAV calculation. You need to run deferrals to generate postings for the income distribution calculation.

title: Accounting tab
body: Choose the deferral type to run and the previous deferral date. If the previous deferral date is empty, the starting date of the fund is used.

title: Accounting tab
body: Accounting rules for income distribution-related postings

title: Accounting tab
body: Accounting rules that are used to generate postings related to income distribution. These rules are specified in the system configuration made by FA consultants. Enter them in the Accounting rules for income distribution-related postings field to change posting status to “Reported” when you accept NAV.

title: Advanced settings tab
body: The Advanced settings tab contains miscellaneous settings for your fund.

title: Unit certificates
body: Setting for unit certificates. To learn more about unit certificates in the FA Fund management app, see the Unit certificate

title: Unit certificates
body: Report template (PDF)

title: Unit certificates
body: The path to the custom Unit certificate template. For example, "/UnitCertificateCustom/Unit certificate".

title: Unit certificates
body: Transaction types

title: Unit certificates
body: Transaction types for the unit certificate to show in the Shareholder registry view. If empty, only the UC type is shown.

title: Pricing of share class without shareholders
body: Define how the unit price for newly created share classes with no shareholders is set:

title: Pricing of share class without shareholders
body: Select the checkbox to use the previous price of the share class.

title: Pricing of share class without shareholders
body: Leave the checkbox empty to use the price from the share class with a higher priority.

title: Allocation
body: Select the checkbox and choose the allocation groups to update share class allocations based on fund portfolio contents when you accept NAV. Allocations are updated for the configured group(s), based on fund portfolio’s allocations on the NAV date.

title: Share class wizardhur
body: The Share class wizard lets you create, edit or delete a fund share class. When you create a share class in the Fund management app, FA creates a share class security with the specified properties in FA Back.

title: Share class wizardhur
body: To add a share class, click the button in the Fund details pane.

title: Share class wizardhur
body: To edit a share class, click the button in the Share class details pane.

title: Share class wizardhur
body: To delete a share class click Delete in the Share class wizard. You can delete a share class only if it doesn't have any transactions and isn't used in benchmarks.

title: Basic info tab
body: Share class details and NAV calculation settings.

title: Basic info tab
body: Code*

title: Basic info tab
body: A unique code defined for the share class. The code is used to identify the share class security and search for securities in the system. We recommend using numbers and letters (a-z) and avoiding special characters in the security code.

title: Basic info tab
body: ISIN

title: Basic info tab
body: The ISIN code of the share class security.

title: Basic info tab
body: Name*

title: Basic info tab
body: Name of the share class security.

title: Basic info tab
body: Type*

title: Basic info tab
body: Share class security type. Choose the type that is configured for funds in Preferences. If you have standard solution configuration, use Collective investment vehicles type.

title: Basic info tab
body: Holiday calendar*

title: Basic info tab
body: A holiday calendar that determines business days and holidays in the market to set a settlement date for subscriptions and redemptions. Holiday calendar options are configured in Preferences. You can also set the default holiday calendar used for new securities in Preferences.

title: Basic info tab
body: Share class priority

title: Basic info tab
body: The order in which share class NAVs are calculated if there are multiple share classes. The NAV for the share class with the highest priority is calculated first.

title: Basic info tab
body: Decimal count for transaction units

title: Basic info tab
body: Number of decimals used in the units field of the client transactions. If the field is empty, the number of decimals set for the security type is used.

title: Pricing tab
body: Unit price settings:

title: Pricing tab
body: Currency

title: Pricing tab
body: Share class currency – the currency share class units are quoted in.

title: Pricing tab
body: Initial price

title: Pricing tab
body: (Set for a new share class). Initial price of the share class unit. Initial unit price is used for the first NAV calculation. The price you enter is copied to the Market data info tab in the Security window in FA Back.

title: Pricing tab
body: Date of initial price

title: Pricing tab
body: (Set when you create a share class). The date for which the initial unit price is valid.

title: Pricing tab
body: Format

title: Pricing tab
body: Unit price multipliers to use in calculations. For more information about multipliers, see the description of the Basic info tab in the Security window. Choose one of the options:

title: Pricing tab
body: Show price as is – Show the share class unit price without any multipliers.

title: Pricing tab
body: In percentage – Use "100" in both Multiplier fields for the security.

title: Pricing tab
body: Add manually – Enter the multipliers in the fields below.

title: Pricing tab
body: Decimals for share class NAV

title: Pricing tab
body: The number of decimals used in the share class NAV. If the field is empty, NAV is stored with 10 decimals.

title: Transaction fees
body: The Transaction fees section contains parameters for subscription and redemption fees and charging them automatically when you calculate NAV. Enter the subscription and redemption fee parameters:

title: Transaction fees

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The Performance fee equalization section contains parameters to calculate and equalize performance fee. In addition to choosing the fee parameters here, you need to define the crystallization schedule in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab, and the fee formula in the Fund wizard, Fee structure tab.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee percentage

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee percentage to calculate the fee amount.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Hurdle rate

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The minimum NAV increase above HWM starting from which the performance fee is paid.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Day count

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Day count convention to calculate the period for which the increase is counted.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: High-water mark

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The initial high water mark (HWM) to use for the performance fee calculation. Usually, HWM is set to the highest NAV value in the share class. On the crystallisation date, FA Fund Management compares the share class NAV to the HWM. If NAV is higher than HWM, the HWM value is updated to the current NAV value.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: High-water mark date

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The date on which high-water mark is set.

title: Cash transactions tab
body: Account settings to handle deposits and withdrawals.

body: Account number

title: Cash transactions tab

body: FX hedging settings:

body: Portfolio

title: FX hedging tab
body: Portfolio that contains the FX forward.

title: Subscription and redemption fees
body: FA Fund Management lets you calculate subscription and redemption fees in the incoming trade orders automatically when you accept NAV. With automatic trade order execution turned on, the system also generates transactions based on the trade orders.

title: Subscription and redemption fees
body: You can calculate the fees as a percentage of the trade amount or as a fixed amount per transaction. The fee parameters are entered in the share class settings. You can also provide a discount on the fee to certain clients by setting the discount percentage in the client’s portfolio.

title: Subscription and redemption fees
body: Trade order amount with transaction fees is calculated in the following way:

title: Subscription and redemption fees
body: Subscriptions executed with trade amount: Trade amount = Subscription amount - Fee

title: Subscription and redemption fees
body: Subscriptions executed with units: Trade amount = Number of units * NAV + Fee

title: Subscription and redemption fees
body: Redemptions executed with trade amount: Trade amount = Redemption amount + Fee

title: Subscription and redemption fees
body: Redemptions executed with units: Trade amount = Number of units * NAV - Fee

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: To set up automatic calculation of subscription and redemption fees:

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: Make sure you have automatic order execution turned on in FA Fund management app (Fund wizard → Order execution tab). To learn more about automatic order execution in funds, see NAV calculation and automatic order execution.

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: Set up transaction fees for a share class. Open the Share class wizard, Fee structure tab in FA Fund management application, and enter the fee parameters:

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: Calculate fee for net trade amount-based subscriptions

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: The amount from which the subscription fee is calculated in net trade amount-based trade orders: order trade amount or the sum invested in the fund.

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: Define default transaction fees

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: Settings for subscription and redemption fees calculated automatically and included in the transaction:

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: Cost percentage

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: Fee percentage to calculate the fee amount.

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: To set the fee as a fixed amount per transaction, enter "0" as a cost percentage and then specify the fee amount in the Minimum field.

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: Minimum

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: The minimum fee amount to charge.

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: Currency

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: Fee currency, automatically set to the share class currency.

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: To define a discount for a client (if needed), open the client’s portfolio, Fees tab in FA Back, and enter the discount parameters:

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: Cost type

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: Cost types for the fee. Choose "Subscription discount" with "DISCS" cost type for a discount on the subscription fee. Choose "Redemption discount" with "DISCR" cost type for a discount on the redemption fee.

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: Value

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: Discount as a percentage from the fee. For example, to execute subscriptions and redemptions without a fee, enter 100.

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: The discount is applied to all future subscriptions and redemptions in all funds.

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: Note that if you define a client discount, the minimum fee amount set on the share class level isn’t used.

title: Set up subscription and redemption fees
body: After you set up the transaction fees, you can see them in the subscription and redemption transactions as you accept NAV.

title: Questions about subscription and redemptions fees
body: I want to set up an exceptional transaction fee for some trade orders. Is this possible?

title: Questions about subscription and redemptions fees
body: Yes, you can define subscription and redemption fees in the Trade order window. Enter the fee percentage in the Internal info field (for example: fee=0.5), or enter the fee amount in the fee field.

title: Questions about subscription and redemptions fees
body: I rolled back NAV and accepted it again, but my fees in trade orders are not recalculated. What should I do?

title: Questions about subscription and redemptions fees
body: We recommend using automatic order execution to have your fees recalculated correctly, Otherwise, you need to check the fee amounts after the rollback as they aren't updated automatically.

title: Portfolio tab
body: The Portfolio tab shows the summary of fund portfolio positions. Amounts are shown in the fund currency ("pf") or share class currency ("sec").

title: Table columns
body: By default, the table includes the following columns:

title: Table columns
body: Security

title: Table columns
body: List of positions in your portfolio shown as a position’s security name or an account name.

title: Table columns
body: Units

title: Table columns
body: Number of units or account balance.

title: Table columns
body: Market unit price (pf)

title: Table columns
body: Market unit price in portfolio currency.

title: Table columns
body: Market price date

title: Table columns
body: The date for which the market unit price is fetched.

title: Table columns
body: Change %

title: Table columns
body: Unit price change since last NAV calculation as a percentage.

title: Table columns
body: Market value (pf, clean)

title: Table columns
body: Market value of the position excluding accrued interest.

title: Table columns
body: Accrued interest

title: Table columns
body: Accrued interest for the position.

title: Table columns
body: Market value (pf, dirty)

title: Table columns
body: Market value of the position including accrued interest, in portfolio currency.

title: Table columns
body: To add or reorder columns, click the icon in the top-right corner. Available columns are:

title: Table columns
body: Security type. Add this column, for example, to be able to filter portfolio positions by security type.

title: Table columns
body: Columns that correspond to values in Analytics+, for example:

title: Table columns
body: Values related to position price, costs and charges.

title: Table columns
body: Cashflow values.

title: Table columns
body: Profit and return values.

title: Table columns
body: Interest values.

title: Table columns
body: The values are based on current day’s snapshot. Some values might not be meaningful when viewed for a single day.

title: Table columns
body: The set of columns you chose is shown only to your user. Each user can choose the position information to view.

title: NAV report (PDF)
body: NAV report contains details of NAV calculation that you can see in the NAV window tabs. You can download NAV report in PDF format in the NAV window (see NAV window for details).

title: NAV report (PDF)
body: The Summary of calculated NAV section shows the summary of the current NAV calculation.

title: NAV report (PDF)
body: The Details of calculated NAV section shows details for each NAV calculation item: Market value of investments, Accrued interests, Account balances, Receivables, Liabilities, Fees. (See the Table rows description in the NAV summary tab).

title: NAV report (PDF)
body: The Summary of share class NAVs section shows NAV calculation by share class (see the Table columns description in Share classes tab).

title: NAV report (PDF)
body: The Portfolio section shows portfolio positions (see the Table columns description in Portfolio tab). You can choose the portfolio position information that is included in the report. To do this, select the columns in the Portfolio tab by clicking the button before you generate the report.

title: NAV report (PDF)
body: The Warnings section shows four types of warnings generated as a result of NAV calculation. For details, see the Warnings tab section.

title: NAV report (PDF)
body: The Limits section shows post-trade limits analysis generated when you calculate NAV. You need to set up the limits for your fund in FA Back to get this information displayed in NAV report. For details, see Limit definitions.

title: NAV report (XLSX)
body: NAV report contains details of NAV calculation that you can see in the NAV window tabs. You can download NAV report in the XLSX format in the NAV window (see NAV window for details).

title: NAV report (XLSX)
body: The Preview summary section shows the summary of the current NAV calculation.

title: NAV report (XLSX)
body: The Share classes section shows NAV calculation by share class (see the Table columns description in Share classes tab).

title: NAV report (XLSX)
body: The Portfolio section shows portfolio positions (see the Table columns description in Portfolio tab). You can choose the portfolio position information that is included in the report. To do this, select the columns in the Portfolio tab by clicking the button before you generate the report.

title: NAV report (XLSX)
body: The Warnings section shows four types of warnings generated as a result of NAV calculation. For details, see the Warnings tab section.

title: NAV report (XLSX)
body: The Limits section shows post-trade limits analysis generated as a result of NAV calculation. You need to set up the limits for your fund in FA Back to get this information displayed in NAV report. For details, see Limit definitions.

title: Role management view
body: Role management view lets you add, edit and delete user roles, and group them into departments.

title: Role management view
body: User role defines which applications the users can access, and user rights within the app. Roles are grouped by department. For example, Analytics department group might include the Data analyst, Economist, and Fund analyst roles, with each role providing access to certain apps and actions within those apps.

title: Add role button
body: The add role button lets you create a new role. Click the button and fill in the fields:

title: Add role button
body: Department

title: Add role button
body: The department where the role belongs. Choose the department from the list or create a new one by typing it in.

title: Add role button
body: Role

title: Add role button
body: The name of the user role.

title: Add role button
body: After you created the role, define the role rights by clicking in the Role pane on the right.

title: Filters
body: You can filter user roles by department, role name or application.

title: Table columns
body: Role

title: Table columns
body: Departments and roles under each department.

title: Table columns
body: Access to applications

title: Table columns
body: The applications the role provides access to.

title: Role pane
body: The Role pane on the right lets you view, edit and delete the role. To open the Role pane, select the role from the list.

title: Role pane
body: To change the role's department or edit the role name, click . To edit the role rights, click and make changes in the Rights window (see Rights window for details). To delete a role, click .

title: Department pane
body: The Department pane lets you edit department name of delete a department. To open the Department pane, select the department from the list.

title: Related links
body: Access to FA functionality in FA Admin guide

title: Related links
body: User management view in FA Admin Console reference

title: Rights window
body: The Rights window lets you view and modify what rights are included in the role. To open the Rights window, click in the Role pane on the right in the Role management view.

title: Rights window
body: You can filter and search user rights by application, role, or description.

title: Manage user roles
body: You can add, edit and delete user roles, and group them into departments.

title: Manage user roles
body: User role defines which applications the users can access, and user rights within the app. Roles are grouped by department. For example, Analytics department group might include the Data analyst, Economist, and Fund analyst roles, with each role providing access to certain apps and actions within those apps.

title: Add user role
body: To add a user role:

title: Add user role
body: Go to the Role management view in the FA Admin Console and click Add role.

title: Add user role
body: Fill in the fields:

title: Add user role
body: Department

title: Add user role
body: The department where the role belongs. Choose the department from the list or create a new one by typing it in.

title: Add user role
body: Role

title: Add user role
body: The name of the user role.

title: Add user role
body: Click Submit.

title: Add user role
body: Edit the role rights. Choose the role and click . Set the rights in the Rights window and click Save.

title: Add user role
body: After you defined the user role, you can assign it to the users. For details, see Assign user roles

title: Edit user role
body: You can change the role name, the department it belongs to, and the rights provided by the role. To edit a user role:

title: Edit user role
body: Go to the Role management view in the FA Admin Console and click the role from the list.

title: Edit user role
body: To edit the role name or change the department, click in the role details pane on the right. To edit the rights provided by the role, click and set the rights in the Rights window.

title: Edit department name
body: To edit the department name, go to the Role management view in the FA Admin Console and click the department from the list. Click to edit the department name.

title: Related links
body: Role management view in FA Admin Console reference

title: User list
body: The User list lets you view the users, their status and authentication settings in one table.

title: Filters
body: The filters at the top of the list let you search for a user by their ID, name, or email, or filter users by the linked contact, roles, status, or last login date.

title: Edit buttons
body: Edit buttons let you manage the users you selected:

title: Edit buttons
body: Force password reset on next login

title: Edit buttons
body: Force the user to reset their password on next login.

title: Edit buttons
body: Add/remove roles

title: Edit buttons
body: Edit the user roles for the users you selected. To learn more about user roles, see User details pane.

title: Edit buttons
body: Activate/deactivate users

title: Edit buttons
body: Switch the status of the users you selected. Deactivated user can’t log in to FA. We recommend using this option instead of deleting the user – this maintains the user's history while preventing them from accessing FA.

title: Table columns
body: User ID

title: Table columns
body: User ID used to log in to FA and log the user's activities.

title: Table columns
body: First name, Last name

title: Table columns
body: The user’s first and last name.

title: Table columns
body: Email

title: Table columns
body: The user’s email used to send a password reset link to the user if the user clicks Forgot password? on the login page.

title: Table columns
body: Linked contact

title: Table columns
body: The corresponding contact in FA Back. Linked contact is used to set up restricted access to the data stored in FA. Learn more in the User details pane section.

title: Table columns
body: Roles

title: Table columns
body: Roles assigned to the user. By default, the column shows the app the user can access. Click Expand all to view more detailed information that includes access rights within the app.

title: Table columns
body: To view users with a certain role, use the Roles filter at the top. We don't recommend sorting users by the Role column as it might take time.

title: Table columns
body: Status

title: Table columns
body: The user’s status: active (can log in to FA) or inactive (can't log in to the system).

title: Table columns
body: Last login

title: Table columns
body: Date and time of the last login.

title: Table columns
body: Two-factor

title: Table columns
body: An indicator showing if two-factor identification is turned on for the user. With two-factor authentication, users are required to enter a verification code in addition to their basic credentials (user ID and password) when logging in to FA. Learn more in the User details pane section.

title: File management view
body: The File management view allows you to access system-level files and troubleshoot file-based integrations, FA Back and FA Front configurations, and themes.

title: Folders list
body: File management view provides you access to the following folders:

title: Folders list
body: fa-back – Files received and generated for file-based integrations.

title: Folders list
body: keycloak-custom-themes – Custom login page themes.

title: Folders list
body: keycloak-custom-spi – Extensions for authentication, for example against in-house identity provider (JAR files).

title: Folders list
body: routes – Routes for client-specific integrations with the FA Connector microservice.

title: Folder details pane
body: The details pane on the right shows the file or folder information and lets you open a folder, download a file, rename, copy, move or delete. To open the details pane, double-click a folder or a file from the list.

title: Create and upload buttons
body: To upload a file or create a new folder, use the buttons at the top. The total size limit for files and folders to upload is 500MB per upload.

title: Create and upload buttons
body: To delete multiple files, select them from the list and click the Delete selected files button (available from 1.2 onward).

title: FA audit logs
body: FA audit logs let you track user activities related to sensitive customer data and changes in preferences that can modify the business logic.

title: Customer information logs
body: FA records logging in and out, opening windows, making selections on Overview, searches, report generations, PDF and XLS exports. Each audit trail entry includes details about the user, time, and screen, and information the user accessed or exported.

title: Changes in system settings
body: FA tracks changes in system settings that can affect FA functionality and system logic.

title: File format
body: File format preferences provide you with configurability on the import file format.

title: File format
body: Delimiter for CSV files

title: File format
body: Delimiter character used in your FA Format CSV files. Enter a single character such as semicolon (;) or a comma (,). By default, FA Format import files are semicolon-separated.

title: File format
body: Encoding to use for importing

title: File format
body: CSV file encoding: Windows-1252 or UTF-8. By default, Windows-1252 is used. Choose UTF-8 if your import data includes non-ASCII characters, for example, such letters as "å", "ä", "č", "ē".

title: Reader format configuration
body: Reader format configuration defines settings for for importing transactions, trade orders and market prices in custom files. Custom files can have column names and content that differ from the ones used in FA format. However, your custom file must contain a minimum of required columns, see  Required fields in custom importers.

title: Reader format configuration
body: To define a custom importer, click Add and fill in the fields in the Basic info and Format mapping tabs.

title: Basic info
body: Enter the basic information about the importer:

title: Basic info
body: Name

title: Basic info
body: The importer name (shown in the Import window when you upload the file).

title: Basic info
body: Read from line

title: Basic info
body: A number that sets how many header rows the importer must skip.

title: Basic info
body: Separator

title: Basic info
body: Separator between the columns, most commonly it is a comma or a semicolon.

title: Basic info
body: Date format

title: Basic info
body: Date format used in the custom file.

title: Basic info
body: Decimal point

title: Basic info
body: The decimal point used in the custom file.

title: Basic info
body: Importer type

title: Basic info
body: Importer type, depending on what information the file contains: Transaction, Market price, or Trade order importer.

title: Format mapping
body: The Format mapping tab defines how to map the fields between the FA file format and your custom file. It appears when you fill in the basic info and click Next . Pick up the columns from the list on the left and move them to the right (=>) in the order they appear in your custom file. To remove a column from the File format, click <=. The Skip column button marks a custom file column that the importer must skip. It adds an empty column to the File format field.

title: Format type
body: Format type describes the type and format of the column data. Choose one of the following:

title: Format type
body: Default format type that matches the FA file format. For example, in FA file format transaction type is a string that contains transaction code, such as “B” (buy), “S” (sell), and so on. If your custom file uses the same values, choose the default format type.

title: Format type
body: MAP_TYPE. Choose this option if the column values don’t match the values used in FA file format.

title: Format type
body: TRANSACTION_TYPE_MAPPING_EXPR maps transaction types in your custom file to transaction types configured in FA. For example, you can define that transaction type "BUY" corresponds to transaction type "B" configured in FA. To do this, list transaction types in the Value field as "<custom value>=<FA value>". Use the separator you defined in the Basic info. For example, “Sell=S, Buy=B”.

title: Format type
body: EXT_PORTFOLIO_ID_NAME defines which external portfolio ID is listed in the custom file. A portfolio in FA can have several external IDs that are defined in the Portfolio window, IDs tab (see Portfolio window, IDs tab). To let FA know which external portfolio ID is used, specify ID name in the Value field, for example, "Nordea".

title: Format type
body: FIXED_VALUE writes a fixed value in the import file column. For example, you can use this option to pass an FX rate if it isn't specified in your custom file. To do this, enter one of the following in the Value field:

title: Format type
body: A number – for example, if you want to use a constant FX rate and pass it in one of the fields, specify "1.2" (use the decimal point you defined in the Basic info).

title: Format type
body: The AUTO automatic value that fills in the column cells automatically. For example, for the FX rate column "AUTO" will fetch the transaction day's market price of the transaction's currency. For more information about how to use AUTO, see File formats for importing transactions and trade orders.

title: Preferences - Tags
body: Tag preference s allow you to easily find the settings for different types of tags. These tag preferences are available from FA 3.11 onward - if you are using an older version of FA, see Preferences - General - Tags instead.

title: Tags
body: Tags

title: Tags
body: Tag preferences allow you to configure the tags available for your contacts, portfolios, securities, transactions, trade orders, accounts and documents.

title: Tags
body: Tag preferences are divided into sections, and each section allows you to define tags available for different kinds of data. In addition, each of the sections allows you to easily see all tags you have available in the system.

title: Tags
body: Contact tags are available for your contacts in the Contact window.

title: Tags
body: Document tags are available for the documents you upload into the system through document management.

title: Tags
body: Portfolio tags are available for your portfolios in the Portfolio window.

title: Tags
body: Portfolio's account tags are available for your portfolio's accounts in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab.

title: Tags
body: Representative tags are available for portfolio contacts in the Portfolio window, Contacts tab, for contact representatives in the Contact window, Representatives tab, and for portfolio asset managers in the Portfolio window, Asset managers tab. Representative tags can be used to specify the representative's role (for example, parent, company owner, and so on).

title: Tags
body: Security tags are available for your securities in the Security window.

title: Tags
body: Transaction tags are available for your transactions in the Transaction window.

title: Tags
body: Trade order tags are available for your trade orders in the Trade order window.

title: Tags
body: Tags within each section are listed alphabetically within a tree structure, where options within a group tag are shown under the group. You can easily see the type of the tag (standalone or group) and the visibility of the tag (whether the tag is restricted so some users or data).

title: Tags
body: You can manage the tags within each section through an easy-to-use form:

title: Tags
body: Type - select whether you want to create a Standalone tag, Single-select group or Multi-select group. Tag type determines how the tags is shown in the user interface and how you can select the tags for your corresponding data. Single-select group tags are shown in a drop down, allowing you to select one tag within the group, while multi-select group tags are shown as checkboxes, allowing you to select multiple tags within the group. Standalone tags are shown under Other tags, allowing you to select them one-by-one.

title: Tags
body: Name - define a name for your tag. This is the name of the standalone tag or the name of the group shown in the corresponding window.

title: Tags
body: Tags within a group - only available for group tags, allowing you to define the options within your group tag. The order you define your tags within a group affects the user interface: the tags are shown under the group in the order you have defined them in Preferences. If you want to change the order your option appear within a group, just change the order you define them in Preferences.

title: Tags
body: In addition, you can flexibly control your tags' visibility based on various criteria, including which users can use the tags and which data the tags are visible on. This provides you with tools to ensure only relevant tags are visible for your users - tags with restricted visibility are still visible through “hidden tags”, but you cannot add them manually to your data.

title: Tags
body: Restrict this tag to be shown to roles - allows you to show the tag in the corresponding window only to the users with a specific role. Choose the user roles from the list of roles defined in the Admin console app (for details, see User details pane). If left empty, all users can see this tag.

title: Tags
body: Define criteria for when this tag is shown - allows you to control the tag's visibility based on characteristics of your contacts, portfolios, securities or transactions / trade orders, i.e. to show the tag in the corresponding window only for certain kinds of data. Define as a comma-separated list of criteria that needs to be fulfilled for the tag to be shown. If left empty, tag is always shown. For example, syntax “group=FUND,type=INV;ASSET,language.code=EN” would show a portfolio tag to portfolios which belong to group “FUND” and which have either type “INV” or “ASSET” and which have language “EN”.

title: Contact window
body: Contact window allows you to create a new contact or to view and edit the information of existing contacts. You can create a new contact through the menu in New - New contact, and you can view the information of existing contacts by double-clicking a contact either from your search result on the Contacts view or from the Overview.

title: Contact window
body: You can define the basic information of the contact in the first tab, and use the other tabs to define additional information for the contact. In the Basic info tab, the contact type determines the role of the contact in the system: a contact can be for example a customer, when portfolios can be added to the contact, or an asset manager.

title: Basic info
body: The Basic info tab allows you to define the basic information of the contact, such as ID and name. A red star indicates that a field is mandatory.

title: Basic info
body: The available fields are:

title: Basic info
body: Contact ID*. An individual ID defined for a contact. The contact ID separates a contact from other contacts (the system does not allow more than one contact with the same contact ID). The contact ID is used to identify and search for a contact, and many of the import functions utilize the contact ID. Best practice is not to include special characters into the contact ID - only use numbers and letters (a-z).

title: Basic info
body: Contact name*. Name of the contact. Avoid the ">" character in the beginning of the contact's name - this will confuse the contact as a group when selected on the Overview.

title: Basic info
body: External ID. A general ID for identifying a contact, for example, identity number or social security number.

title: Basic info
body: Status*. The status of the contact: Active, Passive, or Closed.

title: Basic info
body: Type*. Choose the contact type from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Contact types. The contact type affects the functions you can perform on a contact: for example, portfolios can be added only to contacts of the type Customer, and only contacts of the type Asset manager can be added as asset managers.

title: Basic info
body: Juridical form*. Choose the juridical form from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Juridical form. The juridical form of a contact affects the juridical form of a portfolio added to the contact: the default juridical form of a portfolio is the juridical form of the contact of the portfolio. However, the changing of the juridical form of the contact doesn't affect the juridical forms of the existing portfolios assigned to the contact. The juridical form affects the taxation of certain transactions added to the portfolios: when creating corporate actions, the tax associated with these is defined as a combination of juridical forms and tax countries of the portfolio.

title: Basic info
body: Classification* . Choose the classification from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Classification.

title: Basic info
body: Classification 2 and 3 . Choose the classification from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Classification.

title: Basic info
body: Identity*. Choose the identity from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Identity.

title: Basic info
body: Tax country*. Choose the tax country from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Countries. The tax country of a contact affects the tax country of a portfolio added to the contact: the default tax country of a portfolio is the tax country of the contact of the portfolio. However, the changing of the tax country of the contact doesn't affect the tax countries of the existing portfolios assigned to the contact.

title: Basic info
body: Nationality. Choose the nationality from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Countries.

title: Basic info
body: Language. Choose the language to be used in portfolio reports from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Language. The language of a contact affects the language of a portfolio added to the contact: the default language of a portfolio is the language of the contact of the portfolio. However, the changing of the language of the contact doesn't affect the languages of the existing portfolios assigned to the contact. The language chosen for a contact determines, which language is used in the portfolio reports when creating a report: the reports are created in the language of the portfolio. The translations for the security and transaction types to different languages are defined in Preferences - Internationalization. If no language is selected, the reports are printed out in Finnish and the abbreviations defined for security and transaction types are used.

title: Basic info
body: Transaction no. level. Choose from:

title: Basic info
body: Portfolio level - the system automatically generates a transaction number for a transaction, which is individual to each transaction within the portfolio.

title: Basic info
body: Contact level - the system automatically generates a transaction number for a transaction, which is individual to each transaction within all the portfolios of the contact.

title: Basic info
body: Tags. Choose tags from the alternatives defined in Preferences - General - Tags. Tags can be defined in three different ways:

title: Basic info
body: Grouped tags (select one): you can select one tag from each tag group, grouped in separate drop downs. Only one tag in each tag group can be chosen. To group tags in a drop down, defined them with a hyphen as "group - tag", for example Reporting - 1m or Office - Helsinki.

title: Basic info
body: Grouped tags (select multiple): you can select multiple tags from each tag group, grouped as separate sets of check boxes. You can check multiple tags within each tag group. To group tags as a set of check boxes, defined them with a colon as "group : tag", for example Hobbies : Golf and Hobbies : Food&Wine.

title: Basic info
body: Individual tags: search for individual tags by typing the tag in the field and choosing the correct tag from the list below the field - all available tags are show from the downward arrow on the keyboard. You can select multiple individual tags.

title: Address info
body: In the Address info tab, you can add address information to a contact. You can simultaneously maintain multiple different addresses, for example "home address", "office address", "primary address" - whichever address information you need to maintain.

title: Address info
body: Add a new address with the Add address button, and define the address information in the available fields. A red star indicates a mandatory field.

title: Address info
body: Name* - the name of the address, the only mandatory field.

title: Address info
body: Address 1 - address.

title: Address info
body: Address 2 - address.

title: Address info
body: Zip code - postal code of the address

title: Address info
body: City - city of the address

title: Address info
body: Country - country of the address

title: Address info
body: Email - email address

title: Address info
body: Phone - phone number

title: Address info
body: Fax - fax number

title: Address info
body: Permission to use electronic communication - select, if electronic communication, such as email, can be used.

title: Address info
body: Permission to send marketing materials - select, if marketing material can be sent to the contact.

title: IDs
body: The IDs tab allows you to define external IDs for your contact. These IDs are used by other parties to identify the contact, and can be used for example to store LEI codes, CIF numbers or any other external Customer IDs.

title: IDs
body: Add a new ID with the Add ID button, and define the ID information in the available fields. A red star indicates a mandatory field.

title: IDs
body: External name* - the name of the ID (or who uses the ID, where is it from). When starting to type in an ID, the system automatically suggests ID names you have used previously.

title: IDs
body: External ID* - the external ID for the contact.

title: Representatives
body: The Representatives tab allows you to define representatives who can access the client’s portfolios and contact information. A representative is a user who manages and is responsible for the contact, or who otherwise represents the contact - for example, an advisor can represent their clients, or a private person can represent their company or children.

title: Representatives
body: To add a representative, click Add representative and choose the representative's contact from the drop-down menu. If you have representative tags set up in preferences (see Preferences - Tags), you can use them to specify the representative's role for information purposes (for example, parent, company owner, and so on).

title: Representatives
body: To learn more about linking a representative to contact, see Set up limited visibility for one user and Set up limited visibility for many users.

title: Settlement place
body: The Settlement place tab allows you add settlement places defined in settlement place preferences as the contact's settlement place ( for more information, see Preferences - Securities). Settlement places are for example defined to "Counter party" contacts when generating SWIFT messages from the system to settle trades - settlement place is then used to select the settlement place / exchange the counter party operates in and to define the account information of the counter party in the exchange.

title: Settlement place
body: Add a new settlement place with the Add settlement place button, and define the settlement place information in the available fields. The required information depends on the requirements from the settlement place and what you are using the settlement place information for.

title: Settlement place
body: Settlement place - select the settlement place you want to add, i.e. select the settlement place your want to settle trades with this counter party.

title: Settlement place
body: Name - shows the name of the selected settlement place.

title: Settlement place
body: Code - shows the code of the selected settlement place.

title: Settlement place
body: Define the account information of the contact within the selected settlement place:

title: Settlement place
body: Counter - define the counter information, usually as a BIC code.

title: Settlement place
body: Agent - define the agent information, usually as a BIC code.

title: Settlement place
body: Account - define the account information.

title: Key figures
body: Key figures tab allows you to store a time series of values of your choice - you can for example store fee percentages that change over time or a tax value on your contact. See Key figures for contacts, portfolios and securities for more details.

title: Memo
body: Memo allows you to write optional information, notes or observations related to the contact. The contents of the memo are also shown in the Memo section on the Overview, when the contact is selected.

title: Memo
body: You can also import texts to the memo from a file through Import - Import contact memo, or to edit the contents of the memo directly from the Memo section on the Overview.

title: Documents
body: Documents allows you to manage documents related to your contact. For more information, see Document management.

title: Processes
body: The Processes tab allows you to run processes for your contacts, if contact-related processes have been defined for you in FA.

title: Saving a contact
body: Saving a contact saves the contact into the system, and after you save the contact, you can for example create portfolios to it. When editing the information of an existing contact, the system just updates the contact information - the updated information is picked up by the system automatically.

title: Saving a contact
body: At the bottom of the Contact window, you can:

title: Saving a contact
body: Save and close - saves the contact / the changes made to the contact information and closes the window.

title: Saving a contact
body: Save - saves the changes made to the contact information, and takes you back to the Basic info tab.

title: Saving a contact
body: Copy as new - copies all of the existing contact's information as a base for you to create a new contact with a new ID. This function copies all other contact information except for the Contact ID, since this information is contact-specific and related to only one single contact.

title: Related links
body: Manage contacts in FA User guide

title: Portfolio window
body: Portfolio window allows you to create a new portfolio or to view and edit the information of existing portfolios. You can create a new portfolio through the menu in New - New portfolio, and you can view the information of existing portfolios by double-clicking a portfolio either from your search result on the Portfolios view or from the Overview.

title: Portfolio window
body: The basic information for the portfolio is defined in the Basic info tab, and other tabs are used to define additional information for the portfolio. Remember to check that the portfolio has a customer as a primary contact in the Contacts tab, and if you are tracking cash balances in your portfolio, remember to add appropriate accounts in the Accounts tab.

title: Basic info
body: Basic info tab allows you to define the basic information of the portfolio, such as ID and name. A red star indicates that a field is mandatory.

title: Basic info
body: The available fields are:

title: Basic info
body: Portfolio ID*. An individual ID defined for a portfolio. The portfolio ID separates a portfolio from other portfolios (the system does not allow more than one portfolio with a same portfolio ID). The portfolio ID is used to identify and search for a portfolio, and many of the Import functions utilize the portfolio ID. When creating a new portfolio, if the "Generate a running number for portfolio ID automatically" is enabled in Portfolios Preferences, the next available number is automatically set as the portfolio ID. Best practice is not to include special characters into the portfolio ID - only use numbers and letters (a-z).

title: Basic info
body: External ID. A general ID for identifying a portfolio, for example insurance number.

title: Basic info
body: Status*. Select your portfolio's status between Active, Passive or Closed. The status allows you to categorize your portfolios, for example to differentiate between portfolios you are actively managing and portfolios you have already closed. Recommended status to use for portfolios you are actively working with is Active - such portfolios are shown everywhere in the system, and you can work with active portfolios on the Overview. Passive and Closed portfolios are not selectable on the Overview (to avoid cluttering the list of portfolios you are actively maintaining) - you can still access portfolios regardless of their status through the search views.

title: Basic info
body: Changing the status doesn't "remove" the portfolio from the system, just hides it away from the Overview - you can, for example, still generate reports for passive portfolio through a group, portfolio's contact, or generate a report from the Portfolios view.

title: Basic info
body: Valuation method*. Choose the valuation method of the portfolio:

title: Basic info
body: FIFO

title: Basic info
body: Average price

title: Basic info
body: FIFO with adjustments , Average price with adjustments – The "with adjustments" options use transaction types that control the market value of the positions with the transaction's trade amount, such as Private Equity transaction types.

title: Basic info
body: Average price with separate items – The "with separate items" option valuates your portfolios with average price, but keeps track of original purchase dates.

title: Basic info
body: FIFO (combined) – The combined option valuates the portfolio based directly on transactions in the subportfolios.

title: Basic info
body: Portfolio name*. Name of the portfolio.

title: Basic info
body: Type*. Choose the portfolio type from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Portfolio types. The portfolio type can be for example Investment portfolio or Insurance portfolio.

title: Basic info
body: Aggregation of subportfolios. Choose the method to aggregate positions from subportfolios in reporting and analytics (this feature is only available for the new 3.0 reports and Analytics+):

title: Basic info
body: Sum up values – Aggregate the position amounts without currency conversion. Use it if the subportfolio currencies are the same as the main portfolio currency.

title: Basic info
body: Recalculate values – Aggregate transactions from subportfolios and convert the amounts to the portfolio currency (using the FX rate valid on the transaction date). Use this option if you have subportfolios in different currencies than the main portfolio currency.

title: Basic info
body: Locked. Allows you to Lock your portfolio to prevent anyone from manually adding, modifying or deleting transactions or trade orders within the portfolio. If you try to change the transaction or trade orders within a locked portfolio, you will be notified that Your portfolio is locked! Locking a portfolio allows you to freeze your portfolio's contents from manual modifications, or for example collateralize assets by moving them to a locked sub-portfolio to prevent making modifications to the collateral.

title: Basic info
body: Even when your portfolio is locked, you can still execute trade orders that have already been marked as executable, run corporate actions, and import transactions and trade orders to your portfolio.

title: Basic info
body: Custody. Choose the custody of the portfolio from the alternatives, which are defined by creating a new contact of the type Custody.

title: Basic info
body: Book entry. Define the book entry number for the portfolio.

title: Basic info
body: Currency*. Choose the default currency for the portfolios from the alternatives, which are defined by creating a new security of the type currency. The default currency of a portfolio defines the currency used when creating reports for the portfolio, and the transactions are recorded in the portfolio default currency.

title: Basic info
body: Source. Define the method for determining the Close market price for the securities in this portfolio. The chosen method Default, Manual, Close 1, 2, 3, 4 or 5 describes, which prices saved for a security are taken into account when determining the close price for the securities in this portfolio. The market price source is defined on a security level, but if the source of a security is Default, the source can be overridden on a portfolio level (e.g. for certain portfolios, the Close 2 prices of securities can be used even though the securities are set to use the default close prices).

title: Basic info
body: Language. Choose the language to be used in portfolio reports from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Language. The default language of a portfolio is the language of its primary contact. The language chosen for a portfolio determines, which language is used in the portfolio reports when creating a report: the reports are created in the language of the portfolio. The translations for the security and transaction types to different languages are defined in Preferences - Internationalization. If no language is selected, the reports are printed out in Finnish and the abbreviations defined for security and transaction types are used.

title: Basic info
body: Juridical form*. Choose the juridical form from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Juridical form. The default juridical form of a portfolio is the juridical form of its primary contact. The juridical form affects the taxation of certain transactions added to the portfolios: when creating corporate actions, the tax associated with these is defined as a combination of juridical forms and tax countries of the portfolio.

title: Basic info
body: Tax country*. Choose the tax country from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Countries. The default tax country of a portfolio is the tax country of its primary contact.

title: Basic info
body: Creation date. Define the creation date of the portfolio.

title: Basic info
body: Start-up date. Define the start-up date of the portfolio.

title: Basic info
body: Update date. Define the update date of the portfolio.

title: Basic info
body: Model portfolio. Choose a model portfolio for the portfolio, which is used in the portfolio rebalancing (an optional extra to FA Portfolio). When a model portfolio is linked to the portfolio, the portfolio can be rebalanced to match the model portfolio, and the system automatically creates trade orders to buy and sell securities.

title: Basic info
body: Posting rule. Choose the posting rules used for the portfolio from the alternatives that are defined in Preferences > Bookkeeping > Posting rule. For more information, see Posting-based bookkeeping.

title: Basic info
